TextEquiv.Unicode: from them, that is, in a hard and dan
gerous time. The marriage doth sig
nifie the bond whereby we are knit to
Christ in saith, and the holy Ghost.
This yet not withstanding, the godlie
man doth still rejoyce. Hee doth with
giving of thankes, and temperancie
both eate and drinke so much as is suf
ficient, and is delighted also in these
externall giftes of God: but when hee
feeleth that the bridegroome is readie
for to depart, or that he is nowe al
readie almost departed out of his
heart, that is, when hee feeleth that
the spirit is extinguished by the fleshes
wantonnesse, and that sayth doth
once beginne to be colde, then doth hee
settle himselfe to prayer and doeth ap
point a solemne fasting, thereby ei
ther to keepe the bridegroome still, or
else to pull him backe being readie to
departe.
But neither publique nor private
fasting can abide to be enforced. For
they will not be compelled, but desire
to proceede of a free, theerefull, and
voluntarie minde. Unwilling men
doe nothing well. God requireth a
chearefull giver. Moreover, let fa
stings be moderated according to the
qualitie of places, persons, perils, and
temptations: if they be not continual,
yet let them be often, till such time as
we be delivered and ridde utterly of
them. Let them be without supersti
tion and fained hypocrise as our Lord
in the first of S. Mathewes Gospell
hath taught us. Herewithall doe the
wordes of S. Hierome agree very wel,
which he wrote to Nepolianus tou
ching fasting, as followeth, Prescribe
to thy selfe so long a time to fast in, as
thine abilitie will suffer thee to beare.
Let thy fastings be pure, uncorrupt,
simple, moderated, and not super
stitious. What availeth it to eate no

from them, that is, in a hard and dan gerous time. The marriage doth sig nifie the bond whereby we are knit to Christ in saith, and the holy Ghost. This yet not withstanding, the godlie man doth still rejoyce. Hee doth with giving of thankes, and temperancie both eate and drinke so much as is suf ficient, and is delighted also in these externall giftes of God: but when hee feeleth that the bridegroome is readie for to depart, or that he is nowe al readie almost departed out of his heart, that is, when hee feeleth that the spirit is extinguished by the fleshes wantonnesse, and that sayth doth once beginne to be colde, then doth hee settle himselfe to prayer and doeth ap point a solemne fasting, thereby ei ther to keepe the bridegroome still, or else to pull him backe being readie to departe. But neither publique nor private fasting can abide to be enforced. For they will not be compelled, but desire to proceede of a free, theerefull, and voluntarie minde. Unwilling men doe nothing well. God requireth a chearefull giver. Moreover, let fa stings be moderated according to the qualitie of places, persons, perils, and temptations: if they be not continual, yet let them be often, till such time as we be delivered and ridde utterly of them. Let them be without supersti tion and fained hypocrise as our Lord in the first of S. Mathewes Gospell hath taught us. Herewithall doe the wordes of S. Hierome agree very wel, which he wrote to Nepolianus tou ching fasting, as followeth, Prescribe to thy selfe so long a time to fast in, as thine abilitie will suffer thee to beare. Let thy fastings be pure, uncorrupt, simple, moderated, and not super stitious. What availeth it to eate no
oyle, and to seeke out such seldome
fond cates, as are harde to bee come
by, as figges, pepper, nuttes, dates,
pure flowre for overfine breade, and
honie? The gardens with digging
for novelties, are turned over and
over, beacuse wee will not eate
common cribble breade, and so while
our daintie mouthes seeke after deli
cates, our soules are pulled from
the kingdome of Heaven. I heare
moreover, that some men there are,
which (contrarie to nature) refuse to
drinke water and feede upon breade,
but sucke uppe and swallowe verie
costly suppings, daintie hearbe
broths, and the juce of Beetes, not out
of a cup, but out of a shell. O shame,
blush we not at such fond toyes, and
are wee not ashamed of such supersti
tion? Thus much sayeth Hierome,
And it is evident, that even at this
day this vice is especially received a
mong our wealthie and religious
men.
But the end of Christian fastings,
are, that the Church, or sinner shoulde
submitte and humble them selves be
fore the Lord, that the flesh would be
obedient and subject to the spirite, that
the flesh should not hinder the sinner
to worke righteousnesse, and that the
intent and minde of him that prayeth
shoulde bee the more earnestly bent
toward God. For fasting is of the
number of those workes, which of
themselves are not absolute and per
feit, but have an other meaning, for
which they are ordained to an other
ende and purpose: therefore fasting
is a certaine helpe to the prayers
and vertues of godly men Where
uppon in the Prophetes wee finde,
that the fastings of the Jewes dis
pleased the Lorde: for they did naught
else but fast alone, that is, they did at

oyle, and to seeke out such seldome fond cates, as are harde to bee come by, as figges, pepper, nuttes, dates, pure flowre for overfine breade, and honie? The gardens with digging for novelties, are turned over and over, beacuse wee will not eate common cribble breade, and so while our daintie mouthes seeke after deli cates, our soules are pulled from the kingdome of Heaven. O shame, blush we not at such fond toyes, and are wee not ashamed of such supersti tion? Thus much sayeth Hierome, And it is evident, that even at this day this vice is especially received a mong our wealthie and religious men. But the end of Christian fastings, are, that the Church, or sinner shoulde submitte and humble them selves be fore the Lord, that the flesh would be obedient and subject to the spirite, that the flesh should not hinder the sinner to worke righteousnesse, and that the intent and minde of him that prayeth shoulde bee the more earnestly bent toward God.
